dialogues.ROBIN:
[1]No!... I took the bread. 
[2]They're not interested in truth. You are too weak, Peter. You would not live through it. 
[3]And this is English courage. 
[4]You speak English? 
[5]What I would give for an English sword. This is a pruning hook. 
[6]Hmm!   Not bad. 
[7]Why should we trust you? 
[8]He makes a point. 
[9]A good point. 
[10]Whatever blood is in his veins, he does not deserve to die here. 
[11]Five years I've waited for the smell of free air. That makes a man fast. 
[12]Amen, brother. 
[13]God willing, we may now be safe. 
[14]Come, Peter.    We must hurry. 
[15]Hold on to my shoulder. 
[16]I swear it. 
[17]Farewell, friend. God speed you on your way. 
[18]I go to England. 
[19]England?   Why? 
[20]Go your own way. I relieve you of your obligation. 
[21]And if I don't want you? 
[22]Robin of Locksley. You know a short route to England, Aslan? 
[23]Home.    Thank you, Lord. 
[24]My friend, you have escorted me home. I beg you to free yourself of your vow. Return with the boat. I know how heavy your heart must be, this far from your family and native land... 
[25]I thought you'd say that. 
[26]Come, Aslan. By nightfall we will celebrate your honor when we dine with my father. 
[27]Why must you walk in back of me? 
[28]Our races have fought for a hundred years to prove that point. 
[29]For an 'infidel' you have uncommon clarity of thinking. Yet you refuse to tell me about your home and family. 
[30]You speak my language. You have the diplomacy and honor code of a nobleman. I ask again, why were you to be executed? 
[31]So, I must continue with my guesswork. You are highborn? Probably... You fell from favor... Clearly... Why? You broke the law? You were a rival for power? ... A woman? 
[32]By the Lord, that's it! 
[33]They say there are Arab women of such beauty that they can possess a man's mind, that he would be willing to die for them. Is that not so? 
[34]Your people must marry women chosen for them by others, right? 
[35]Who is she? The Mullah's daughter? ... Another man's wife?... That's it! 
[36]You dog! You painted old dog! What is her name? 
[37]Her name? 
[38]Her name? 
[39]Ah, Jasmina!    Is she beautiful? 
[40]That way. 
[41]I would know blindfolded. I'm five miles from home... Was she worth it? 
[42]Hold!... I am curious as to what manner of creature is so fearsome that it takes six men to attack it. 
[43]Have we treed the devil himself? Let me see... Ah ha! A small boy. A truly dangerous animal. 
[44]Wrong. This is my land, and my tree. Therefore, whatever is in it also belongs to me. 
[45]The man who strikes that tree dies. 
[46]Perhaps we could discuss this. 
[47]Aslan!   It's time to redeem that vow. 
[48]Aslan, get off your damn knees! I have four of them cornered. 
[49]I hope there's enough of me to satisfy you all. 
[50]Aslan!! 
[51]On your knees, Gisborne.   Pray. 
[52]Now get off my land. And tell your cousin the Sheriff what happens to his scum when they pick on my people. 
[53]You worthless savage! You travel ten thousand miles to save my life, then leave me to be butchered. 
[54]Which does not include prayer times, meal times, or any time I'm outnumbered six to one!! 
[55]Barely. 
[56]After six years of the stench of death, I have no stomach for needless blood on my hands. 
[57]Have no fear, boy. 
[58]Ha!   It was you he was scared of. 
[59]Come, my strange friend. Beyond that hill lies the prettiest little castle in all Christendom. Warm hearths, hot food, real beds. 
[60]With feather pillows. Warm and soft like Jasmina's embrace. 
[61]Father!    Hello! 
[62]Noooooo! 
[63]I should have been here. 
[64]Damn you, Duncan. Why didn't you cut him down? 
[65]You left my father to hang like a common thief, carrion for the crows. 
[66]What has happened? 
[67]Did they have witnesses? 
[68]Did you believe the charges? 
[69]Who did this to you, Duncan? 
[70]Our last words in this world were spoken in anger. He called the Crusades a foolish quest, said it was vanity to force other men to our religion. He was right. Please forgive me, Father. 
[71]I failed him. I should have been here at his side. 
[72]Leave me. 
[73]Leave me. 
[74]I swear by my own blood. I will not rest until I have restored my father's name. ... Or until I am dead. 
[75]We make a fine army, do we not, Duncan? A blind man, an Arab, and a fool. 
[76]This is summer. 
[77]Why, pray? 
[78]You despair too soon, Aslan. We shall find food and shelter here among friends. 
[79]Peter's home. It is nearly seven years since we left here together. 
[80]Open up! 
[81]Tell the mistress of the house that Robin of Locksley is at her door. 
[82]Aagh! 
[83]Is the child Marian at home? 
[84]I am Robin of Locksley. 
[85]I may meet my maker soon from lack of sustenance. But for now I am real enough. 
[86]By heaven, am I to dance next? Who are you? 
[87]Then show yourself, child.     For we knew each other well. 
[88]You know I am not one of them. Besides, I am sworn to protect you. 
[89]Allow that years of war and prison may change a man. Step forward, Marian, so I may see how you have changed. 
[90]Er... the years have been kind. 
[91]Wait, Marian!    ...ouch! 
[92]You are truly courageous against an unarmed man. 
[93]Marian. 
[94]We were together five terrible years in a Saracen prison. 
[95]Marian, I'm sorry. 
[96]On my return, I found my father dead. The Sheriff denounced him as a Druid and took our lands. 
[97]Why do you not join your mother in London? You would be safer there. 
[98]The you must allow me to be your guardian. 
[99]Marian, I don't want to replace him. 
[100]I killed some of the Sheriff's men. I fear I have placed you in danger. 
[101]I'm not leaving. 
[102]Damn the girl! Aslan, can you ride? 
[103]He can ride. 
[104]Damn you, animal! 
[105]Of course I've had a woman! Come on, pretty one. 
[106]I know!   I know! 
[107]Easy, easy. 
[108]I love you! 
[109]What is your pleasure, Gisborne? 
[110]You survived one meeting.    Our next will be your last. 
[111]That's a lie! 
[112]We have lost them. I'll lame this mare if I ask her to go any farther. 
[113]Is this Arab magic? 
[114]God knows! 
[115]We can lose them in the forest. 
[116]Either we take our chances with the ghosts, or become ghosts ourselves. 
[117]They're not following. 
[118]Be quiet!    Listen. 
[119]Behind you! 
[120]No, there!    And there! 
[121]Here are your ghosts, Duncan. A child's toy put to good use. You scare easily, my painted Saladin. 
[122]Aslan! 
[123]I beg of no man. Which of you scum has guts enough to face me man to man? 
[124]Er... Robin... 
[125]...Hood.   Robin Hood.   Who are you? 
[126]Bestman?   You lead this rabble? 
[127]Tax?   For what? 
[128]I will pay no tax. Besides, I have nothing but my cloak and my sword. 
[129]That is sacred to me. 
[130]You will have to fight me for it. 
[131]This man is your father? Tell him how I saved your hide from the Sheriff's soldiers. That deserves some gratitude, I believe. 
[132]Aslan! 
[133]Son of an Arab whore! Once again your assistance was invaluable. 
[134]That rabble? 
[135]They have a leader.   A very large one. 
[136]Allah has taken your brains. 
[137]You, too? You expect me to fight that behemoth? 
[138]This is my bridge. No one crosses without paying tax. 
[139]If you wish to cross, it will cost you a gold medallion. 
[140]You don't have the courage to face me again, John Little? Or should I call you 'Little John'? 
[141]Do you yield? 
[142]Do you yield? 
[143]Good.   Now put your feet down. 
[144]Pay me the tax. 
[145]A fine brew, Little John. 
[146]You owe me nothing, Wulf. I am glad I chanced by in time to help. 
[147]Tell me about your men, John. 
[148]How do you come by the name, Bull? 
[149]Because you are short? 
[150]No, Bull.    Save it for the ladies. 
[151]Your name, friend? 
[152]Hold! Hal, you have the face and hands of a farmer. I wager you are a strong and honest man, and I'd be glad to have you at my side in a fight. The next man who makes light of you will have to answer to me. 
[153]How is it there are so many of you in hiding? 
[154]How do you fare? 
[155]While the Sheriff steals your land and your families starve? 
[156]Your ghosts will only keep his men at bay so long, my friend. Soon the Sheriff will hunt you down and hang you. You must fight back. 
[157]We must organize. Win by guile. 
[158]No.   To lead you. 
[159]There are many here who knew my father to be a kind and generous man. I doubt that in their hearts they believe him capable of such a horror. 
[160]What is your name, friend? 
[161]He is right to distrust me. I am a rich man's son. I have done no honest labor. But today I am as poor as any of you. Nottingham has stolen all that I own. And when I killed Gisborne's men, I, too, became an outlaw. 
[162]We can win.   And I believe we will. 
[163]English dogs.    They can learn. 
[164]Too much mead, old friend.    What day is it? 
[165]Good. Do they still give alms to the poor at the mass? 
[166]Then I must ask you a favor. 
[167]Pardon my blindness, sir.    I'm always falling down. 
[168]Alms for a blind man. For one who cannot see your beauty. 
[169]So you care for my safety? 
[170]Under the Sheriff's law, that's a badge of pride. 
[171]How much? 
[172]Is that all? I have not annoyed him enough. Soon he will offer ten thousand. 
[173]How do you know? 
[174]What is he planning? 
[175]If you need me, I will be with the woodsmen. Send for me as 'Robin Hood.' 
[176]What? 
[177]Care to join me? 
[178]A hundred crowns, Sheriff?   You insult me. 
[179]Remember young Robin of Locksley, Sheriff? Meet Robin Hood. Your nemesis. Your avenging angel. 
[180]If I kill you, I will hang happy. 
[181]I want to give you a chance. A chance you do not deserve. A chance to right your wrongs. 
[182]From this day forward you will cease to tax my people. You will renounce the charges against my father, and you will return his lands to me. 
[183]Because for every harm you do, I swear by God I shall visit on you threefold in return. 
[184]I am here with a blade at your throat. As long as I live, you will always know that I could be here again. 
[185]Your answer? 
[186]Then it will begin.. 
[187]A personal loan from the Sheriff. 
[188]How so? You have not raised a finger to protect me. 
[189]It was my choice to do this alone. 
[190]Aslan, if I didn't know better, I would swear you were worried about me. 
[191]Then we shall take from him and his rich friends. 
[192]Will, do you think the Sheriff will give everything back after I am gone? 
[193]Alright, Will. You can take me in on one condition. You must fight me. You may use the Sheriff's horse and arm yourself as you please. I will fight on foot. Unarmed. 
[194]If you lose, you will accept me as your leader. If you win, you may take me in. Dead or alive. 
[195]I am grateful for your concern, friends, but I have to prove to them it is possible to overcome unequal odds. I am ready, Will. 
[196]Come on, you little piss pot. Do your worst! 
[197]The horse is smarter than you are, Will. 
[198]Here, Will!   You aim like a girl, Will! 
[199]Thank the Lord you are not endowed like Bull. 
[200]Nottingham has taken from us everything we own. Now we are going to start taking from him. 
[201]We are going to tax him. 
[202]How many? 
[203]Twenty?   They usually have five. 
[204]This is no ordinary convoy. 
[205]Er, about ten. Why scare them? They can't count anyway. 
[206]Let's go. 
[207]Surrender your weapons. I give you my word you shall go free. 
[208]Ah, I feared as much. 
[209]This treasure had a purpose.     We must find out what. 
[210]Get off him.   He's a man of the cloth. 
[211]It appears to me, Reverend Friar, that many of the libations have found their way into your own esteemed person. 
[212]A moment, my reverend friend. You travel with poor company when you travel with Nottingham's soldiers. 
[213]My men are thirsty and have much to celebrate. 
[214]Surely the Lord has the charity to spare a few barrels to good Christian men. 
[215]You leave when I say. 
[216]Never!   Whoomf! 
[217]Yield yourself! 
[218]Yield to Robin Hood. 
[219]Well, Friar Tuck. We have need of an honest man of God, to minister to these men and their families. What do you say? 
[220]Giddyup, Friar. 
[221]What do you say now, Tuck?    Here are the meek of the earth. 
[222]You will not regret it. 
[223]Buy yourself a new son, Stephen. 
[224]I believe you. But this Arab here, he's got it into his barbarian brain that you know a whole lot more than nothing. 
[225]And when he gets like this, he's very hard to reason with. 
[226]I strongly advise you to talk. He hasn't eaten in weeks. 
[227]You. 
[228]No, Aslan... not this one, Aslan. ... How about this other one?... Fatter, yes... more meat. 
[229]I cannot stop him, John. Besides, if they will not tell what they know, then they must pay the price. 
[230]Well, roughly, he says that he doesn't care for the way your friend tastes, and he wants you. 
[231]Thanks to our cannibal friend. 
[232]To hire mercenaries. The Celts are savage tribesmen, trained to kill from birth. 
[233]Since he also has every Smith in the country working in his castle, we can assume he is planning a little war. 
[234]Good morning, Lady Marian. 
[235]Ah well... er, let me finish this bath you wished me to take. Then I'll explain. 
[236]If you will be patient, I could spare your propriety by... 
[237]As you wish. 
[238]Nottingham robs the poor. We rob Nottingham and give back to the poor. 
[239]Somebody has to take a stand. 
[240]Nottingham was sending this gold to buy reinforcements from the Celtic tribesmen. We need to warn King Richard. 
[241]The King is not in England to be challenged, is he? While he is away, he may lose his country. You are Richard's cousin. You can get word to him. He would believe you. 
[242]I am sending Duncan with you. Give him some warm food and a real bed. I grow tired of his bellyaching. 
[243]Don't tell him I told you, but he may be useful to you. There is no one to whom I would rather entrust your safety. 
[244]Will you send word to the King? 
[245]We have to be ready to move camp at any time. The only way we can be attacked is from the Nottingham Road. We hide lookouts in the trees, here and here. If they see soldiers, they shoot warning arrows. Whistles by day, fire by night. 
[246]The good Friar has done all he can. I suggest you let the Arab try. If I am wrong, and they die, then you may take my life. 
[247]What are you going to do? 
[248]The knife? 
[249]Horses? By the Lord, what are her chances? 
[250]Now you tell me! 
[251]Is she gone? 
[252]What did you say? 
[253]The dancing demon! Good morning. 
[254]They need help. 
[255]Are you sure it was a Druid mask? Damn them to hell! They must have Marian. Do you know where they meet? 
[256]No! You stay here, dammit!    I will go alone. 
[257]Then be my friend. There are women and children here in greater need of your courage. 
[258]Marian! 
[259]Why, Marian? 
[260]I love you. 
[261]Where is Marian? 
[262]Marian? 
[263]You have fulfilled your vow.   Now you can leave. 
[264]You ignored my request. 
[265]Because of you, another good man is dead. 
[266]To hell with your damn vow. 
[267]The forest!   Ride! 
[268]Wulf, stay here. I need your horse. 
[269]What are you doing?    Out of my way! 
[270]Out of my way, damn you! 
[271]You were an honor to your countrymen today, Aslan. You fought better than twenty English knights. 
[272]Well, the war is over. 
[273]There is too much blood on my hands. 
[274]My pride brought us to this. 
[275]I gave them nothing but false hope. Tomorrow we will disperse. These people can move south and start over. You must go home and win your Jasmina. 
[276]I am no longer your responsibility. 
[277]Damn you, Arab. I want you out of my life. Can't you understand that? Go home. Go back to your own kind. 
[278]Damn you, too, Father.   You reared a coward and a fool. 
[279]Will!    I thought you were taken. 
[280]How did you escape? 
[281]And will you? 
[282]John, wait.    Let us hear what he has to say. 
[283]A traitor sneaks in and out under cover of darkness. Will walked in and announced himself. 
[284]Let him speak. 
[285]You were to use this news to get close to me, and then kill me? Right, Will? 
[286]What is your intention, Will? 
[287]How so? 
[288]You present quite a choice.    What would you have me do, Will? 
[289]And if I stay, will you all stay with me? 
[290]There's your answer, Will.    We finish it. 
[291]Will it work? 
[292]You are truly a wizard. 
[293]We have no armored knights, no glorious banners. But I am honored to be going to battle in this company. Today we fight not just for the lives of our friends, but to save all England. 
[294]We may be only six men, but... 
[295]Fanny, show me the exact location of the scaffold. 
[296]Friends!   We must raise the gate. 
[297]Light all the barrels, Tuck. 
[298]Jump! 
[299]Where is she? Where is Lady Marian? 
[300]Ah!   There is my answer. 
[301]Marian, run!   It's me, Robin. Run! 
[302]I warned you, I would find you no matter what. 
[303]Watch out! 
[304]This is for my father. 
[305]I'm your sworn protector.   Any way I see fit. 
[306]I think she's feeling better. 
[307]It will mend. 
[308]Aslan, my friend. 
[309]Here, Tuck. Look after him.    You deserve each other. 
[310]Who would dare refuse his king's request? 
[311]We are deeply honored by Your Majesty's presence.
dialogues.ASLAN:
[1]Because I love them so dearly, I cannot dishonor them. 
[2]No man controls my destiny. Especially not one who attacks downwind and stinks of garlic. 
[3]If our positions were reversed, I would have done the same. Only I would have succeeded. 
[4]In your land am I not the infidel? The unbeliever, the instrument of evil? 
[5]Then I trust it is safer to appear as your slave than as your equal. 
[6]Those are my burdens. 
[7]It is close to sunset. 
[8]Endless clouds. Is there no sun in your cursed country? 
[9]Which way is East? 
[10]East? 
[11]East?!!! 
[12]Damn you!... Jasmina. 
[13]Which way is East? 
[14]Are you sure? 
[15]Worth dying for. 
[16]I will fulfill my vow when I choose. 
[17]You whine like a mule.   You are still alive. 
[18]A flesh wound. Why did you let their leader go? 
[19]The conquering hero returns. 
[20]With feather pillows? 
[21]Easy... Look at him. 
[22]Come, friend. 
[23]Like a rock. 
[24]It surprises me that one who curses others so readily has lived so long. 
[25]Er... no. 
[26]A fine Saracen name. 
[27]Lord, yes. But eat in peace. I take no offense. By the prophet! What is the man doing? 
[28]Wait! 
[29]A fine, wet army. I have never witnessed a storm of such duration. When does summer come to this land? 
[30]Then Allah truly is great. 
[31]No food, no shelter,   and weather that would curse the   end of the earth. We  will all   quickly be dead, and I shall be   rid of my vow. 
[32]What is this place? 
[33]The hospitality here is as warm as the weather. 
[34]Robin! The old man hears horses. Approaching fast. 
[35]Twenty or more. In battle armor. 
[36]Treat it like a woman. 
[37]Have you never had a woman? Gently, man. Soothe it! 
[38]Softly.   With your knees. 
[39]Come, Robin! He is trying to anger you into a trap. 
[40]Here they come. Look. 
[41]No.    Arab science. 
[42]How did your uneducated kind ever take Jerusalem? 
[43]Allah protect us from the evil spirits. 
[44]Cease your mad laughing.     I can feel them. 
[45]You seemed more in danger of losing your pride than your life. 
[46]Your avenging army, my friend. 
[47]All they need is a leader. 
[48]Defeat him and they will follow you. 
[49]With regrets, I decline. 
[50]On the contrary. I thank you, but my faith prevents me from partaking in such enjoyments. 
[51]I have led you wrong. This is no army. These men live like dogs. 
[52]Learn what?   To build kennels? 
[53]You should not have left without me, Englishman. 
[54]Before I had a choice. 
[55]A foolish risk. If you had been killed, I would be cursed for eternity for failing to fulfil my pledge. 
[56]This man has true purpose.    He means to kill you. 
[57]Here they come. 
[58]Two wagons.   Twenty escort. 
[59]And they call me the barbarian. 
[60]Perhaps it is time for some heathen persuasion. 
[61]England. 
[62]By Allah, leeches! 
[63]Blood is like air. If she loses blood, she and the child will die. 
[64]Fool, both the Bible and the Koran instruct us to preserve life. 
[65]Your baby has not turned. It cannot be born without help. 
[66]If you will allow me, I can help her. It will not be without danger. 
[67]If you do not listen to me, she will certainly die. And the child, too. 
[68]Bring me a needle, thread, water, a skinning knife, and burning ashes. 
[69]The child must be taken out by the knife. 
[70]I have seen it many times with horses. 
[71]After wasting so much blood... not good. 
[72]Are you ready?... Bite down on this... Robin, hold her steady. 
[73]It is a boy. 
[74]Your son, my lady... Robin, hold her skin together while I sew her up. 
[75]Alas, I am not permitted... 
[76]This must be a truly evil potion, to make the soul feel this good. 
[77]Come, holy man. A toast to all of Allah's children. The true believers and the fat infidels. 
[78]If it was Jehovah who created this brew, he is truly wise. He built the punishment into the crime. 
[79]We will go there. 
[80]You forget yourself.   I am not your servant. 
[81]Take my eyes, then. 
[82]Behind you! 
[83]They have poisoned you. There are herbs that can alter a man's brain. I know of only one cure. 
[84]It worked for me this very morning. You will thank me for this later. 
[85]Your gratitude warms my heart. 
[86]It is fortunate that I did. 
[87]He urged me to bring him. He was a brave man and I grieve for him. Praise be to Allah that I do not grieve for you also. Or for my broken vow. 
[88]I am glad you are feeling better. 
[89]I saved your life. I will not let you give it away for no purpose. 
[90]Does the witch still have possession of your senses? If we meet up with the survivors we may yet give them some help. And do some damage to the enemy. 
[91]It was a fiendish mind that planned this campaign. 
[92]This war is the God of Abraham against the forces of evil. 
[93]No, friend. It was you who gave these men pride. 
[94]And you? 
[95]That is for me to decide. 
[96]To the end, friend. 
[97]I have prayed for you, often, my brother. But, let us put prayer aside and help our gods in a more practical manner. I must reveal to you the mysteries of the black powder. 
[98]There is no such thing. But if there was... ... I would surely be one. 
[99]You talk too much! 
[100]Englishmen! I am not one of you, yet I fight for you. Against a tyrant. Join me now. Join Robin Hood. 
[101]For Allah!... For Jehovah! For brotherhood!... For justice! 
[102]Ali akbar! 
[103]What you fear is not below. 
[104]I'm going home the easy way, Robin. 
[105]I have no strength, Brother Tuck. 
[106]Please!   It hurts when I laugh. 
[107]My friend, a word of advice... Ride her better than your horse.
dialogues.NOTTINGHAM:
[1]You are an unwelcome surprise, Locksley. 
[2]I think not. 
[3]One day all England will worship with us. 
[4]Who bade you cover up? 
[5]Cousin, I trust you justify your intrusion with news of profound value. 
[6]His name? 
[7]Ha! The prodigal son returns. He is a whelp. This girl could best him. 
[8]Your men were probably drunk.   Yet you survived, cousin? 
[9]Quiet! 
[10]What do you see? 
[11]London? 
[12]Move the capitol to Nottingham? Excellent. How? 
[13]Put someone on the throne and rule through him? Who? 
[14]Ally with royal blood. What else do you see? 
[15]Whose? 
[16]And victory? 
[17]Whose? 
[18]What is wrong? 
[19]Cousin. Prove to Locksley that your survival was his last mistake. 
[20]Kill them both. 
[21]You have done well, Mortianna. Exceedingly well. No one shall harm you, I swear it. 
[22]Now, my child, Mortianna's kisses will seem soft, like an angel's. Take her. You have earned her. 
[23]Fear not for my sanity, Guy. For in madness, there is great power. 
[24]You shine like the sun, my lady. 
[25]You have been meeting with young Robin of Locksley. My cousin tells me the knave deprived you of some horses. 
[26]I deeply regret it, and I promise you he will be brought to justice. For subjecting you to such treatment, I will hang him from the walls with his own entrails. 
[27]My dear, a woman of your refinement is not safe living alone. If you would consent to bring your household within the city walls, I could give your needs my most personal attention. 
[28]Alas, the King has many enemies both abroad and at home. I fear for his safe return. 
[29]If you kill me, you will hang. 
[30]What do you want? 
[31]I'm listening. 
[32]Why should I? 
[33]Empty words. 
[34]Never, fool. 
[35]Starve them out. Slaughter their livestock. I want to see Locksley's own people fighting each other to bring him to us. 
[36]Spanish steel, cousin. So much stronger than our native blades. Any losses? 
[37]Yet again you are the sole survivor, cousin? Interesting. And the gold? 
[38]Robin Hood? 
[39]Robin Hood. 
[40]Cousin, we must be strong. We cannot allow this outlaw to make fools of us. 
[41]And I cannot allow a lieutenant to fail me. It is indeed fine steel. 
[42]How can we control all England if we cannot control our own county? The people are turning him into a hero. 
[43]Then we   will be more cunning. I must be   rid of him. We may not be able   to intercept his next warning   to the King. 
[44]Welcome, sir. We were discussing how to rid ourselves of those very men. The outlaws who band with Robin Hood. 
[45]This rat Hood has hidden out in the forest.  He resists all our assaults with traps and devices, while he robs us blind. We must bring him out and destroy him. 
[46]I want prisoners. 
[47]Nevertheless, I need prisoners. 
[48]Would you prefer pain or death? 
[49]Torture him. 
[50]And you?   Pain or death? 
[51]Torture him... you see, it makes no difference. 
[52]You will all be tortured. You will all tell me all you know about Robin Hood, and then you will all be hanged. Then we will catch your beloved Robin Hood and do the same to him. 
[53]Why would I need you? 
[54]And you can succeed? 
[55]If you fail, I will personally cut out your lying tongue. 
[56]His friends will.. ... torture him! 
[57]It will look better. 
[58]How is my bride? 
[59]Ah... You are overwhelmed with happiness. 
[60]When we are married, thirty of the northern barons will pledge me their support as king. As you predicted. 
[61]What do you see in the portents? 
[62]Di not give me riddles, woman. We are to be married within hours. How can we be in danger? 
[63]Tell me how it will result. 
[64]Confound you, crone. Without my protection, the people would hunt you down, rip out your black heart and burn it. 
[65]Ah, the turncoat. Did you succeed? 
[66]Stretch his neck with the others. 
[67]Locksley, here? Where ? 
[68]Release him!... Now, where is he? 
[69]We will find him. 
[70]Put Hood in my hands, you go free. 
[71]Damn your worthless hide!    Just tell me where he is. 
[72]You'll get your reward. Where is he? 
[73]Step down, friar. 
[74]This man claims you have outlaws concealed in these barrels. Among them the cursed Robin Hood. 
[75]Break one open! 
[76]Here's another message to Robin Hood, written in your blood. 
[77]Lower the portcullis! Now! 
[78]Too slow, fool! 
[79]Seal the entrance. Guard it with your lives. ... Bring the bishop to my chapel. 
[80]Come!   It is time for the union. 
[81]Marry us. When I am declared king, that rabble will not dare go against us. 
[82]No companions? No army? You rush to your death for the sake of a woman. Lust has turned you into a fool... Recognize this, Locksley? 
[83]Appropriate I should use it to kill you with, don't you think? 
[84]You should have stayed away, Locksley. Fools like you never learn. 
[85]What can your puny God do for you now?
dialogues.LITTLE JOHN:
[1]Mead.   Made it m'self. 
[2]Real honey. 
[3]An Englishman's mead not bleedin' good enough for ya? 
[4]Your bloody loss, mate. 
[5]What is it, boy? Speak up! 
[6]C'mon, lad, drink! 'Twill put hair on your bloomin' chest. 
[7]This stumpy one 'ere's David o' Doncaster. We calls 'im Bull. 
[8]That be Hal Brownwell, but the lads call i'm Hal Hiccup. 
[9]We're outlaws. Got prices on our 'eads, every man jack. Blasted Sheriff says we owes 'im taxes. 
[10]We get by, I reckon. 
[11]What in bloody blazes'd ya have us do? 
[12]We show as much as a toe outside the forest, they'll slaughter us like bleedin' sheep. 
[13]'We'? Ya lookin' to join us, matie? 
[14]Stuff a flippin' cork in it, Will. The man's our guest. 
[15]That there's Will Scarlet. Pay 'im no 'eed. 'E's full o' piss and wind. 
[16]Ya're full o'bloody wind an' all, mate. This 'ere load o' rubbish agin the Sheriff's bloomin' army? Ya must be bloody jokin'. 
[17]Ya're a daft bugger, Robin Hood, but ya're a brave 'un, I'll give ya that. Drink up, laddie, cuz tomorrow ya mayn't be so lucky! Tomorrow I shall best ya an' crack that blasted noble head in two. 
[18]Sheriff hasn't left us a bloody pot to piss in. 
[19]Bollocks, Will. Jus' bugger off, eh? 
[20]Ya got us by the short and curlies, Robin Hood. Now let's hear what ya got to bleedin' say. 
[21]'Ow in bloody blazes are we gonna do that? 
[22]I'll be buggered. 
[23]Cain't get a bleedin' squeak outa 'em, Rob. 
[24]Reckon the Cap'n knows summat, Rob, but stubborn ol' cocker 'e is. 
[25]No, Robin, no! They be God-fearin' men. 
[26]Kill 'em aye, but not like this. 'Tain't Christian. 
[27]Sure changed the color of 'is britches, didn't 'e? 
[28]Gonna laugh my bloody balls off. 
[29]Aye, the Romans built a bleedin' great wall to keep 'em out. 
[30]Agin' who? 
[31]Right m'lad. Let's see how close you can git to that bugger. 
[32]Take a gander at this 'un, mates. Never seen nuthin' like it in my bloomin' life. 
[33]Hush, m'lass.    Ya'll be fine. 
[34]Ya're sittin' thar like a fat sow. Help her, man, help her! 
[35]So be it. 
[36]
[37]Ya'll be jus' fine. Lil' smoke ain't gonna kill ya. 
[38]'Ere, lads... Over 'ere! We must make a stand. 
[39]Damn y'all! Ya're no more use than a load o' wet farts. 
[40]Bollocks, Will. Quit yer bloody bellyachin'. 
[41]C... ccc? What the bloody hell ya sayin'? Cows?... Cowards?... 
[42]Stop 'ere and flippin' well fight 'em, that's what. Whadya say, lads? 
[43]Nay, reveren'. Ya best be goin' wi' the wenches. 
[44]Let's give 'em a bloody good wallopin' an' all, lads. 
[45]'Bout bleedin' time, mush. 
[46]Git the bleedin' 'ell outa there, ya li'l bugger. 
[47]Don't 'ee start bleedin' blubberin', or ya'll make me bloody vomit. 
[48]I'll wring yer scrawny neck, Will Scarlet. I'd be doin' yer a bloody favor an' all. 
[49]Git us a rope, Hal, and we'll put the bleedin' weasel outa 'is misery. 
[50]No bugger 'scapes the Sheriff, 'nless 'e's linin' 'is bloomin' pockets. 
[51]Aye.    'E always did 'ave balls o' brass. 
[52]Search 'im, Hal. 'E'll 'ave a bloody blade on 'im somewheres. 
[53]Bugger me. 
[54]Marriage, eh? What lucky wench gits to play with the Sheriff's codpiece? 
[55]Aye, and then with King Richard gone, he takes the bloody throne. 
[56]'E's in. We're all bloody in. Daft buggers. 
[57]What in blazes ya doin', woman? Where's the little 'uns? 
[58]Ya gone bleedin' cracked, girl? 
[59]Ya should be bloody well mindin' the other seven. Tell 'er, Rob. 
[60]Fight fair... 
[61]...Or don't fight at all. 
[62]Come on, ya ckicken-'earted buggers. Ya milksops, ya bleedin' pansies. 
[63]Excuse me, m 'old cock. Ya mind if I borrow this? 
[64]Ya gutless bloody sissies. 
[65]Wulf! I told ya to keep outa the fightin'. 
[66]Well, ya'll get a bloody good wallopin' if we get 'ome... For now, let's see how well I taught ya. 
[67]We done it, mate. We clobbered the buggers.
dialogues.MARIAN:
[1]I trust Lord Locksley has recovered from his indisposition. 
[2]Why would he wish me to be protected by the boy who burned my hair when I was a child? 
[3]How do I know you didn't abandon him there to save your own skin. 
[4]I will forward your condolences to my mother. 
[5]The people fear the Druids so much they'd believe anything. Nottingham would have me burned at the stake as a witch if he thought he could possess my property. 
[6]I will not retreat.     Besides, I have no interest in    life at court. Gossip-mongering and    currying favor. Here I am my     own person. 
[7]I do not need a guardian. 
[8]My brother is dead. You cannot take his place. 
[9]What do you want? 
[10]This is wrong. 
[11]Soldiers coming here?     Is this your protection? 
[12]I can take care of myself. There are horses in the stable. Go! 
[13]Stop them!   They're stealing my horses! 
[14]They're thieves, you imbecile. Bring back my horses, or the Sheriff will know of your cowardice. 
[15]Kiss this! 
[16]Try me again, if you want to leave a hand behind. 
[17]This is dangerous. 
[18]No, for mine. I do not wish to be seen with an outlaw. 
[19]He's put a price on your head. 
[20]A hundred gold pieces. 
[21]For ten thousand I would turn you in myself. Nottingham is mounting an army. 
[22]He has rounded up every blacksmith in the county. He has them holed up in the castle making swords and armor. 
[23]I don't know, but there's no limit to the man's ambitions. Go! 
[24]Robin!   Do something for me. 
[25]Take a bath. 
[26]Yes. A most disagreeable experience. 
[27]I would like to see that, my lord. 
[28]I thank you, Lord Nottingham, from the heart, but for now I prefer to stay in my family's ancestral home. My cousin, King Richard, will be deeply moved to hear of your concern for my welfare. 
[29]Fear not, my dear Sheriff. He will return. When he does, he will wish to reward his faithful subjects. 
[30]Please excuse my clumsiness. 
[31]How dare you! 
[32]You send men to drag me from my home in the middle of the night, like some slave girl? Is this the way the famous Robin Hood treats a lady? 
[33]I demand an explanation right now! 
[34]I will decide when my propriety is compromised. 
[35]How dare you expose yourself to me?! 
[36]This better be damned important. 
[37]Do you think he's going to let you get away with all this? The man is without mercy. He will annihilate you. 
[38]You're taking a stand with the lives of these people. These young ones. 
[39]What do you want from me? 
[40]Nottingham would not dare challenge the King. 
[41]Now you want me to participate in your folly? 
[42]Duncan, you are most welcome. 
[43]I'll think about it. 
[44]It is a personal matter, my Lord, but one of vital importance. 
[45]You will travel to France immediately. You must give this directly into the hands of the King, and him alone. 
[46]My lady-in-waiting will accompany you. 
[47]I appreciate your concern, my Lord, but Sarah is an accomplished rider. I must insist that she goes along. 
[48]Who is there?     Duncan! 
[49]Off, Nicodemus. Go find mice. 
[50]You are still overmatched, soldier. 
[51]Is there something you need, gentlemen? I remember no masked ball on my calendar. 
[52]Death is not to be feared, Robin. Embrace it. 
[53]Drink this. 
[54]Drink. 
[55]Look at me. Listen to me. You belong to me. Your soul is mine. You will obey my every word. Do you understand? 
[56]Because you love me. Say it. You love me. Say it! 
[57]Kiss me. 
[58]Kiss me, Robin. 
[59]I will never marry you. 
[60]Get away from me, you disgusting hag. I will not... augh! 
[61]Let me go!   Who are you? 
[62]Robin?   Oh God, is that you? 
[63]How dare you?!
dialogues.FRIAR:
[1]The Lord's blessing on you, kind sir. These sinners were attempting to steal these libations destined for the monks of St. Catherine's. 
[2]A thousand pardons, sir, but duty beckons. I must hasten on. 
[3]Lord bless me, sir, are these your men? I had mistook them for common thieves. Kindly step aside. 
[4]Well, sir, if you wish them to share in the good Lord's brew... 
[5]... you must best me for it. 
[6]Giddyup, nag! 
[7]Protect me, Lord. 
[8]Yield! 
[9]Confess that Friar Tuck is a better, holier, and braver man than thou art, knave. 
[10]Yield, I say!    Yield to Friar Tuck. 
[11]Thank you, Lord, for teaching me humility. 
[12]I'd rather roast in hell. 
[13]The Lord moves in mysterious ways. I accept. 
[14]Aye, but you may. 
[15]God bless you, sir. 
[16]Ah, the good Lord giveth and the good Lord taketh away. 
[17]Good morrow, brothers. 
[18]The child comes early. 
[19]I am doing all I can. 
[20]Get away from her! 
[21]He lies. He is the devil's seed, sent to lead us astray. 
[22]What do you know, you damned savage? 
[23]Do not listen to him!   He will kill her. 
[24]Then it will be on your head. I have warned you. 
[25]I tell you, the barbarian is killing her. 
[26]This day God has taught me a fine lesson. 
[27]I would be honored. 
[28]You are a good man, my barbarian friend. 
[29]We shall open a barrel together and I shall do my damndest to save your heathen soul. 
[30]Our God made this brew, brother. I merely combined the ingredients. Do you dare to insult his works? 
[31]Come, you son of Saladin. A toast to all of Jehovah's children. The saved and the damned. 
[32]How can these Arabs hold Jerusalem when they can't even hold their brew? 
[33]This holy man believes in doing God's work with his hands. 
[34]Surely you would not harm a man of the cloth? 
[35]You would?   Then to hellfire with you. 
[36]Thank you, Lord. And thank you, Allah. 
[37]Robin Hood! Robin Hood! Robin Hood! May as well be hung for a sheep as a lamb. 
[38]He takes a bride of royal blood? 
[39]If my heathen brother stays, I stay. 
[40]Lord, grant us the courage to endure, and if you're as smart as I believe you are, grant us victory... and the victuals to celebrate it with. 
[41]Will you pray with me, son of Allah? 
[42]The Lord's finest brew for the good Nottingham's fighting men. It has a mighty kick. 
[43]Out of the way. Make way for the Lord's business. 
[44]As you wish, sire. Is there something amiss? 
[45]This man will rot in hell as a knave and a liar. These are libations for the celebration of your lordship's nuptials. 
[46]Why waste fine vintage, my lord? 
[47]My son, there is a holy war being waged outside. Release all these wretches and God shall surely find you a place in heaven. 
[48]The Lord helps those who help themselves. 
[49]Give my regards to the devil. 
[50]Sinners, beware! God's avengers are at hand. 
[51]Repent, heathen! 
[52]Amen! 
[53]So! You sold your soul to the devil? 
[54]Blasphemer! You accuse innocent men of Druid worship while you practice the black arts yourself. 
[55]Think again! 
[56]You die on me, you son of satan, and I swear I'll bury you as a Christian in St. Catherine's Cathedral with a thousand monks chanting prayers for your miserable soul. You hear me? 
[57]A fine friend you are! By the grace of Allah and Jehovah we have won the day, and you want to give up the ghost. I'll pickle your remains in mead, lay you in your grave with a pig for a companion, and mark it with a cross as big as this castle. 
[58]See. There's life in the heathen dog yet. 
[59]By the power vested in me by God's holy church, I now pronounce you husband and wife. 
[60]You may kiss the bride. 
[61]Hurry. We waste good celebration time.
dialogues.WILL SCARLET:
[1]Ring around the rosie! 
[2]Atishoo, Atishoo. We all fall down. Beg for mercy, rich man. 
[3]We waste time. Tax him. 
[4]For passage through Sherwood. 
[5]A man who travels with two servants and claims he's without money, is either a fool or a liar. 
[6]And this one is a liar. Ahah! Gold! 
[7]You must be Robin of Locksley. The blackguard who abandoned us to Nottingham's plundering. 
[8]Oh dear! The little rich boy is lost for words. Thanks for the taxes, Locksley. 
[9]If he's in a hurry to end his mortal misery, help him. 
[10]Don't fool with him. Get him! 
[11]Ha! I would never be led by the son of a Druid. 
[12]Count me not a friend, Locksley. 
[13]You brought this misery on us, Locksley. We can barely feed ourselves. 
[14]Brave talk, Locksley. I say we take the rich boy in. 
[15]He will give us the reward, and our pardons. 
[16]Unarmed? 
[17]Dead, Locksley. 
[18]It's burning for miles, John. It's hotter than hades, and them damn screens ain't worth nothing. 
[19]Where's that damn Locksley?   I'll swear he betrayed us. 
[20]Celts?   Where? 
[21]What are we gonna do, John? 
[22]I will kill him for you. 
[23]All your attempts to kill him have failed. Your army failed. Your Celtic mercenaries failed. 
[24]I am one of his men. He would never suspect me. 
[25]He is a trusting fool. He will believe me. If he doesn't, he will kill me and you have lost nothing. 
[26]And if I succeed? 
[27]I was. 
[28]I promised to kill you. 
[29]Y... e... 
[30]I bring a message from Nottingham. Our men are to be hung in the square on Saturday. At high noon. 
[31]The boy, too.    Ten men in all. 
[32]Their   deaths are a warning. Anyone   who associates with the outlaw   Hood is to suffer the same fate.    Man, woman, or child. Even anyone   who so much as utters his name. 
[33]The hangings are to be part of the celebration for the Sheriff's marriage. 
[34]Lady Marian. 
[35]Not straightway, of course. 
[36]That depends on you, Locksley. 
[37]I've never trusted you, that's no secret. What I wanna know is, are you gonna finish what you started? 
[38]Will ya stay and keep us fightin' till every man jack of us is dead? Or will you run like the spoiled little rich boy I always took you for? 
[39]If you run, I will kill you. 
[40]Sheriff! My Lord Sheriff! I have word for you! Of Robin Hood! 
[41]I found his lair, but alas he still lives. 
[42]...He... He... is here! 
[43]Call off your dogs. 
[44]I want your word, in front of these witnesses. If I tell you, I will go free. 
[45]He is concealed. He is going to free the prisoners and stop the wedding. 
[46]With the reward. Ten thousand crowns. 
[47]The reward! 
[48]Try another. There are many barrels, only a few outlaws. 
[49]Pain or death, you butcher? 
[50]It's over, fool. You can kill my body, but you cannot kill our spirit.
dialogues.GISBORNE:
[1]You owe the sheriff three bushels of flax. 
[2]For starving people, you look fat enough. 
[3]Where is your mate? The man they call Little. 
[4]Is that so? We hear he     is very much alive. Hiding out     in the forest. He probably ran     away to escape your scolding    tongue. 
[5]Seize him! 
[6]This is Lord Nottingham's deer. Is this how you repay the Sheriff for his protection? 
[7]Poachers hang. Either he dies or you die. 
[8]You have deprived us of a hunt, boy. 
[9]The hounds know the scent well. 
[10]Run, boy. Like a deer. Give us some pleasure before you die. 
[11]Unleash them! 
[12]You're not playing by    the rules, boy. Deer don't climb     trees... Perhaps he thinks he's    a game bird. Shall we teach     him to fly? Cut it down! 
[13]Stand back, stranger. This is no affair of yours. 
[14]I advise you to move on, pilgrim. This is the Sheriff's land. 
[15]I grow dangerously tired of your wit... Chop it down! 
[16]Chop down the hooded fool. 
[17]Kill him! 
[18]Set the dogs on him! 
[19]Well, hooded stranger, allow me to know your name before I run you through. 
[20]Robin of Locksley! 
[21]Please, Locksley! No! 
[22]Away, fool. 
[23]I met a hooded man today. He bade me warn you not to harm his people. 
[24]Robin of Locksley. 
[25]This whelp bested five of my men in the blink of an eye. 
[26]You brought her here? 
[27]No one. I have seen no one. 
[28]Locksley has a companion. A dark- skinned foreigner. He had the marked skin of Islam. 
[29]It is madness bringing the hag here. 
[30]You have been sheltering outlaws, Lady Marian. 
[31]You're lucky he didn't steal your virtue too. A crown to the man who brings me Locksley's head. 
[32]Robin of the Hood! Son of the devil worshipper. 
[33]It was I who strung your father's corpse to the castle gate. My pleasure will be in doing the same to you. 
[34]Your father died a coward, cursing your name and squealing like a stuck pig. 
[35]Come on, damn you! There are only three of them. 
[36]I swear he will not live to see the next full moon. 
[37]We were ambushed. In Sherwood Forest. 
[38]All the men are gone. 
[39]Well, it er... disappeared. 
[40]They were woodsmen, dressed in green.
dialogues.DUNCAN:
[1]You must wait... I am sorry you were disturbed, Master. 
[2]You cannot go alone, Master.      Let me ride for help. 
[3]Master, stay!    There is an evil moon tonight. 
[4]Master Robin, is it you? A miracle. I thought God had abandoned us. 
[5]They say they captured him worshipping with the Druids. He signed a confession before the Bishop of Hereford. 
[6]Just one. Kenneth of Cowfall. The Bishop decreed all the Locksley lands forfeit. 
[7]Not even when they took my eyes. 
[8]Guy of Gisborne. With the sheriff looking on. 
[9]He loved you till the end, young master. He never gave up hope of your return. 
[10]You must leave, head north to safety. Gisborne will surely seek revenge. 
[11]I know what you're thinking. But one man can achieve nothing against so many. You would need an army. 
[12]He still stands vigil? 
[13]A curse on the Saracens! Were it not for their ungodly ways, he would never have left. This would never have happened. 
[14]I do not recognize the style of your voice, friend. Are you Irish? A Cornishman? 
[15]What manner of name is Aslan then? 
[16]Lord, no! 
[17]Sherwood is haunted, Master. 
[18]Banshees. They say they fly in your mouth and suck you dry of blood before you can scream. 
[19]I recognized some of the voices. Many were from your father's farms. 
[20]I hear the voice of a spoiled child, Master Robin. I suggest you cease your brave talk of revenge and flee to the north. 
[21]Your father would expect you to act like a man. 
[22]Sunday, I believe. 
[23]They do. These days the need for mercy is greater than ever. 
[24]And you have given him the means. 
[25]Hah! I have endured more hardship in my lifetime than any man here. 
[26]I am sorry, my lady.    There were too many.
dialogues.MORTIANNA:
[1]Change the seat of power. 
[2]Change it. 
[3]Ally with royal blood. 
[4]That is not revealed. 
[5]Armies. 
[6]Yours. Men and weaponry in great numgers. 
[7]Much blood will be spilled. 
[8]Who have you seen?! 
[9]You lie!     A man... A painted man. 
[10]I have seen my death. 
[11]The painted man. He haunts my dreams. 
[12]Kill them!     Kill them! 
[13]And the painted man! Kill him. 
[14]She is with friends. Your resistence is strong, but useless. Sign this. You are a Druid like your father. You consort with the devil. Your confession will be witnessed by the Bishop of Hereford. 
[15]The painted man! 
[16]Hold her! 
[17]The union. The blood of the lion and the house of Nottingham. New faith. New power. New souls. 
[18]If there is no union, there will be darkness, despair, death. Ours! 
[19]The blood does not lie. 
[20]I have told you what I know. 
[21]Without me, you are nothing. You are straw, a fleabite, a speck. Laugh, fool. I birthed you from this body. I stole a babe in this very castle, and killed it so that you might rise in its place. You are my son. Together we are strong. Now is not the time to doubt. Now is the time to believe, to be bold. The bold will prevail. 
[22]Face them, or face me. 
[23]Agh... the painted one!
dialogues.SARACEN:
[1]The king's own. Set me free. 
[2]For pity's sake. Mine is a sentence of death. 
[3]Free me and I will show you a way out. 
[4]If you don't, you are dead men. 
[5]This way! 
[6]You are fast, my friend. 
[7]You will need to be yet faster. 
[8]Poison air.   Hold your breath. 
[9]Save your breath. 
[10]Allah be praised. 
[11]His wound is by the heart.    We cannot save him. 
[12]Come now! Do not fail your friend. Make his sacrifice an act of honor. 
[13]Our way is together. With the speed of Allah. 
[14]Then I go to England. 
[15]You saved my life. I must stay with you until I save yours. 
[16]Only Allah can do that. 
[17]You have no choice... unless you think you can kill me. 
[18]My name is Aslan.
dialogues.FANNY:
[1]You starve us. First the drought, now you take what food we have left. 
[2]He died last winter. 
[3]Norman swine! 
[4]No, Wulf! Don't! 'Twill only make it worse. 
[5]I killed it.   We needed the meat. 
[6]No, Wulf! 
[7]'S not like t'others, John.    Oh God, it pains me so. 
[8]Afore ya kill 'im, John, ask 'im if Wulf be still alive. 
[9]What about my boy? 
[10]Seven! 
[11]Them's safe, wi' my mother. Robin, I been to town an' seen the scaffold and the guard towers. 
[12]You go an' birth eight babies and then you can come an' tell me 'bout hurtin', ya big ox. I ain't gonna sit aroun' an' let one o' 'em die, neither. 
[13]Ain't doin' no 'arm, m'dear. Likes a good 'angin', I do. Luvly view up 'ere, ain't it? 
[14]'Bout time, ya gurt lug. 
[15]We be too late. 
[16]Listen! Outside, your countrymen rise against the Sheriff. 
[17]Is there one man or woman here who does not hate him? Who has not suffered at his hand? Turn that on the Sheriff and his bullies. 
[18]Are you 'urt?
dialogues.JOHN LITTLE:
[1]What are ya, m'old cock? 
[2]John Little.   Bestman o' the woods. 
[3]Sacred to us too, mush. This here'll feed us for a bloomin' month. 
[4]I'd love to, mate. 
[5]Naw ya don't, laddie. 
[6]Is that so? 
[7]And for the laughs. 
[8]Just bugger off, mate, huh? 
[9]Ain't I hurt you a bloody nuff for one day? 
[10]Alright, m'old cock. You wanna nuther good wallopin'? 
[11]Lil' wet behind the ears, mate? 
[12]Swimmin' time again, ol' chum. 
[13]Bloomin' shame. 'E were a brave 'un. 
[14]Help!   Cain't bloody swim. 
[15]Yes! 
[16]I'll be buggered. 
[17]Robin Hood, ya got balls o' solid rock.
dialogues.LOCKSLEY:
[1]It is alright, Duncan. You are Kenneth of Cowfall? 
[2]Who has taken her? 
[3]That may be too late. Kenneth, lead the way. 
[4]Good will overcome, Duncan.      Trust in that. 
[5]Onward then.    What is this place? 
[6]Steady, man. They are to dissuade the faint of heart. Think of Gwen. 
[7]I trusted we were rid of such evil a century ago. 
[8]If it is, I have some Christian steel that will test his hide. 
[9]Gwen? 
[10]Gwen!   Up, girl, up! 
[11]In the name of God! 
[12]Nottingham! 
[13]The King shall hear of this, Nottingham. 
[14]Never. 
[15]Why have you betrayed me?   Why?
dialogues.WULF:
[1]Like a wolf protects sheep. 
[2]My mother lies to protect me. 
[3]Wait, father!    I know him. 
[4]Be careful, Father. He fights like a demon. He walloped six o' Sheriff's men? 
[5]I wanna thankee, Lord Locksley. I owes ya m'life. 
[6]Will is ruthless, Robin.    Guard your back. 
[7]Father!   Come quick.   Mother's dying. 
[8]I promise. 
[9]Will, no! 
[10]He knows you always hated him, traitor. 
[11]If it be your biddin' that this be my last night o' life, Lord, gimme the pluck to die proud. An' look 'ee kindly on my folks an' the young 'uns. 
[12]Sorry, Father. Couldn't help myself.
dialogues.PETER:
[1]It is a lie. I caught him stealing ours. 
[2]That's not true. 
[3]That's for five years of hell. 
[4]No, Robin. 
[5]Don't trust him. 
[6]Robin! 
[7]Thanks. I misjudged you. 
[8]It is mortal.    Leave me. 
[9]My mother... my little sister. Tell them I love them. Tell them I died a free Englishman. 
[10]Take this to my sister. Swear you will protect her for me... Swear it, Robin! 
[11]For England.
dialogues.BULL:
[1]'Cuz o' my size, Sire. 
[2]Nay.   'Cuz I be so long. 
[3]'ow many? 
[4]Aye, tax him. 
[5]They'd be spittin' it out good if they'd knowed anythin'. 
[6]Why'd the Sheriff be sendin' gold north o' the border? 
[7]What does 'e want wi 'em? 
[8]The big 'un did the same to me. 
[9]A bloke wearin' a mask o' the Druids rode by. Tossed 'im down. 
[10]The Gregor Caves, I 'eard tell. 
[11]Ya be sure Sarah gits a Christian burial. Promise me, boy.
dialogues.BISHOP:
[1]We beseech thy blessing, Lord, on all your people, but most especially on our noble Lord Nottingham. Grant him the wisdom to guide and protect our glorious city. 
[2]Grant him also the strength to bring to justice the lawless men who threaten its safety. Help him to stamp out the curse of the dread Druids who would seize from us our children, even as wolves steal the lambs from their mothers. 
[3]I understand, my dear lady. This is my most trusted emissary. 
[4]My dear, I could not vouch for her safety. The journey is fraught with danger. 
[5]As you wish. 
[6]They are rebelling. We must escape. 
[7]Is is madness to delay. 
[8]...your bodies to be bound in immortal wedlock. Do you, Marian Dubois, take... 
[9]No, I swear it, in God's name. 
[10]I am sure you would not strike a man of the cloth.
dialogues.HAL:
[1]C... cccc... 
[2]Cccc... elts! 
[3]Gggg... God help us. 
[4]Let's sss... string 'im up. 
[5]Mmmm... meee... tttt... 
[6]Here... By God... Let's fight 'em! 
[7]It's gg... ggg... g..oh crap! 
[8]Take that, ya mug. 
[9]No!   Fight on. Fight! 
[10]Go' bless ya, Tuck.
dialogues.KENNETH:
[1]My Lord!   Help me. 
[2]My Lord, please! 
[3]They've taken my Gwen.    My daughter. 
[4]Men on horses. In masks. We tried to stop them. My son is dead. 
[5]They came this way, my Lord. 
[6]Nearby the Gregor Caves. 
[7]Druids. 
[8]Is it the devil?
dialogues.SOLDIER:
[1]He's not here, sir. None but the woman and children. 
[2]A kiss for me, Saxon bitch. 
[3]It's not the men we fear, sir. 
[4]You've heard of Robin Hood? 
[5]Then pray he is brought to us before winter. 
[6]We meet again. 
[7]Drop your blade. 
[8]You owe me favors, wench. Bare your breasts... or I will do it for you.
dialogues.GIRL:
[1]Who are you? 
[2]You lie.     Robin is dead. 
[3]Step into the light.    Turn around. 
[4]I am the maid Marian. 
[5]With the king away, these are lawless times. There are outlaws villainous enough to kidnap and ransom a relative of his. 
[6]Protect me? Robin of Locksley was nothing but a spoiled bully. 
[7]Thank you. Now remove yourself from this household. 
[8]As you can see, we are already well protected.
dialogues.OLD WOMAN:
[1]No beggars! 
[2]Her ladyship is not at home. 
[3]Maybe she is. Maybe she isn't. Remove that hand. 
[4]Leave your weapons. 
[5]Just you. 
[6]Wait here. 
[7]Unless Robin Hood takes it first!
dialogues.GUARD:
[1]Hey, you! 
[2]Do I know you? 
[3]My God, you stink! 
[4]Yeech!   Get away from me. 
[5]What you got there, Father? 
[6]I'll warrant. Pass.
